Award.AwardTitle: STTR Phase I: Pilot-scale Advanced, High-Rate Wet Weather Treatment Scale-up and Optimization
Award.AbstractNarration:
The broader impact/commercial potential of this Small Business Technology Transfer (STTR) project is to demonstrate feasibility and determine the capacity of an innovative advanced, high-rate wet weather treatment technology to cost-effectively protect environmental and public health during high-intensity rain events by eliminating sewer overflows and basement back-ups. The wastewater utility industry has demonstrated a great unmet need for reliable, cost-effective, end-of-pipe wet weather treatment as an alternative to expensive long-term plans that emphasize large capital projects. The innovative approach being scaled and optimized during this project seeks to achieve the same or higher level of treatment in 35 minutes as conventional wastewater treatment achieves in 10-14 hours. A lower treatment time means a smaller system footprint and, ultimately, cost savings for the utility and ratepayers. The technology will address customer needs by identifying potential sewer overflow "hotspots" that act as "drains" in the utility sewershed during storm events. Each drain solution would alleviate overburdened collection, conveyance, and treatment systems by treating wet weather flows and safely releasing them into waterways. This innovative technology can also be applied at a water reclamation facility to handle overburden or as a mobile unit during disaster relief efforts.

This STTR Phase I project proposes the evaluation of novel concepts including the application of advanced oxidation processes (AOPs) for wet weather treatment, the combination of rapid solid removal technologies with AOPs, and the use of a sustainable waste material as a catalyst for enhanced hydroxyl radical production in catalytic ozonation. None of the above aspects have been commercially implemented. The work proposed will demonstrate the ability for advanced technologies to be cost-effectively applied for wet weather treatment, disrupting the standard of partial combined sewer overflow treatment by providing a viable option for rapid wet weather treatment that meets or exceeds Clean Water Act discharge standards. These concepts will be applied at a pilot scale treating real wastewater to determine the technical and chemical scaling factors for commercial feasibility. Metrics for success within the research plan include aggressive conventional contaminant removal goals, increased flowrate for overall decreased treatment time and footprint, and a targeted cost ($/gallon treated) analysis to ensure competitive edge in the market. It is expected that the results will further demonstrate the importance of solids removal ahead of AOPs, and the implementation of catalytic ozonation will demonstrate increased efficacy and flexibility as the technology scales.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

POR.DRECONTENT:
INTELLECTUAL MERIT

The intellectual merit of this project focused on addressing novel concepts including the application of advanced oxidation processes (AOPs) in wet weather treatment and the combination of two different primary treatment (solids removal) technologies with AOPs for high-rate wastewater treatment during intense storm events to eliminate raw sewage discharge into lakes and rivers. AOPs are characterized by the formation of a strong oxidant, the hydroxyl radical, which non-selectively breaks down contaminants. The commercialization of this technology will mark the first of its kind for commercial implementation. The work completed in this project demonstrated the ability for advanced technologies to be cost-effectively applied for wet weather treatment, disrupting the standard of partial sewer overflow water treatment by providing a viable option for rapid wet weather treatment that meets Clean Water Act (CWA) discharge permit standards.

Metrics for success in the technical research plan and their outcomes are presented below.

Achieve contaminant removals for organics (biochemical oxygen demand, BOD), solids (total suspended solids, TSS), and bacteria (as Escherichia coli) that met CWA discharge permit requirements

  • Water quality requirements for the Milwaukee Metropolitan Sewerage District?s CWA discharge permit are less than 30 mg/L BOD and TSS, and less than 126 colony forming units (CFU) per 100 mL for E. coli. These requirements were consistently met for a range of influent wastewater conditions (high/low organics, high/low solids, and high/low temperature). On average, treated water quality had concentrations of 17 mg/L BOD, 9 mg/L TSS, and non-detect levels for E. coli.

Maintain performance metrics while decreasing the treatment time from 35 minutes to 25 minutes to reduce full-scale system footprint

  • Treated water quality requirements were met during treatment times ranging from 25 minutes to 117 minutes. Increasing the water flowrate (decreasing the treatment time) also increased oxidant utilization, indicating more efficient system operation.

Establish a cost per gallon of wastewater treated for comparison to other high-rate wastewater treatment technologies  

  • On average, the cost per gallon of wastewater treated for existing wet weather treatment technologies (high-rate minimum-required treatment) is $0.75/gallon. With the data collected during this project and scaled for a full-scale system, the average cost per gallon for the Rapid Radicals Treatment System is $0.60/gallon, with a range of + 20% depending on full-scale implementation size. This demonstrates cost-competitiveness in the market.

BROADER IMPACTS

The broader impacts of this project focused on the validation of technical and commercial feasibility of an advanced, high-rate wet weather treatment system to eliminate sewer overflows and basement backups during intense storm events for which the wastewater utility industry has demonstrated a great unmet need. The impacts included technical, commercialization, and educational aspects.

Results demonstrated feasibility and determined the capacity of this innovative technology to cost-effectively protect environmental and public health during intense storm events. The wastewater utility industry has demonstrated a great unmet need for reliable, cost-effective, decentralized wet weather treatment as an alternative to expensive long-term plans that emphasize large capital projects. The innovative approach scaled and optimized during this project achieved the same level of treatment in 25 minutes as conventional wastewater treatment achieves in 8-14 hours for organics, solids, and bacteria. A lower treatment time means a smaller system footprint and, ultimately, cost savings for the utility and ratepayers.

The technical research accomplished in this project is crucial for successful commercialization of the Rapid Radical Treatment System and enabled the growth of this woman-owned small business (Rapid Radicals Technology, RRT). RRT?s growth during this project led to the creation of six jobs in the Milwaukee, WI region including two subcontractor positions, three contractor positions, and one full-time employee position fulfilled locally.

Through the subaward with Marquette University (MU), graduate and undergraduate student researchers gained experience with fundamental research, technology transfer, and commercialization, helping to instill an entrepreneurial mindset and encourage future commercialization efforts. Two students directly involved in the project offered comments as to the impact of this project on their careers:

  • Alex B. (MU Ph.D. student, Environmental Engineering): ?For me, the hands-on experience of actually creating something to solve a problem cannot be matched by any level of classroom or lab education and is therefore invaluable to my learning.?
  • Jake S. (MU B.S., Civil Engineering ?21): ?Working with Rapid Radicals left me with an impactful experience that played a part in both career and academic paths simultaneously. Having the opportunity to grow with and alongside the company?s technology left me with a lifelong learning experience that I will look back on throughout my engineering experience to come.?

Industry partners including Aqua-Aerobic Systems, Inc. and Black & Veatch gained experience working within a university framework and with academic researchers to commercialize technologies. Representatives from both companies provided valuable insight to RRT?s team during the project, as well as extended their involvement in research activities at MU.


Last Modified: 07/28/2021
Modified by: Paige Peters
